I'm not against GMOs, but I think those fruits aren't considered one because the concers some people have around them stem from introducing genes from other species into the plant and how that may have unforseen consequences. With the watermelons it's the same genome, just multiple copies of it, so the genes were already there from the beginning. Plus, it is a mutation that could very well occur in the natural world by chance, it was just sped up through experimentation, whereas most of the genes added to GMOs are completely new and would require a lot more mutations to get them to appear through random chance, which would be near impossible to happen and thus earning them the GMO status

I’ve often pointed out that GMO is a misleading term. The vast majority of our food supply has been bred and altered over the thousands of years since it first became a crop or domestic animal. I do sometimes pick wild berries and my brother hunts deer, so there is a little bit of the food supply that isn’t genetically modified, or is it? What did deer evolve from. It’s genes have been modified, albeit by nature, from its ancestral species.

In the end, the difference between GMO and non-GMO is tho sophistication of the technology by which the genetic modification was produced.
